The Extended Integer (XInt) Library

Copying and Argument-Passing

By default, the xint::integer class uses copy-on-write, which means that if you copy an integer, the copy and the original share the same storage. They are only assigned separate storage when one of them is changed. This mechanism makes copying an integer (explicitly, by returning it, or by using it as a non-reference parameter to a function) very fast, regardless of its size.

(Unfortunately, this makes thread-safe operation impossible. If you need to use the library from multiple threads, you can disable this behavior by compiling it with the thread-safe option.
